title: Erigon rpc `eth_blockNumber` stuck at `0xe8f8ec` after synced
body:
#### System information

Erigon version: `./erigon --version`

Node synced with:

```
./build/bin/erigon --version
erigon version 2022.07.4-alpha
```

and now running with:

```
./build/bin/erigon --version
erigon version 2022.08.1-alpha
```

OS & Version: Linux

```
Linux ethnode 5.15.0-43-generic #46-Ubuntu SMP Tue Jul 12 10:30:17 UTC 2022 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

#### Expected behaviour

As the node is already fully synced:

```
curl http://127.0.0.1:8545 \
  -X POST \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  --data '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"eth_syncing","params":[],"id":67}'
{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":67,"result":false}
```

The method `eth_blockNumber` should return the value of the newest block number. 

#### Actual behaviour

However, it keeps returning `0xe8f8ec`:

```
curl http://127.0.0.1:8545 -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" --data '{"method":"eth_blockNumber","params":[],"id":1,"jsonrpc":"2.0"}'
{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"result":"0xe8f8ec"}
```

which is 15268076 in decimal, while the newest block is actually at 1529xxxx.

However, when invoking `eth_getBlockByNumber` with the newest block number (1529xxxx), it works. 

```
curl -s htt-s http://localhost:8545 \                                                                                                               130 â†µ    -X POST \
    -d '{"method":"eth_getBlockByNumber","params":["0xe97160", false],"id":100,"jsonrpc":"2.0"}' \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json"
```

But this still returns `0xe8f8ec `:

```
curl -s h-s http://localhost:8545 \    -X POST \
    -d '{"method":"eth_getBlockByNumber","params":["latest", false],"id":666,"jsonrpc":"2.0"}' \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json"
```

This is basically the same as the bug mentioned in #2870. However, my `./build/bin/integration print_stages` shows a different result:

```
./build/bin/integration print_stages --datadir=/mnt/node_data/erigon
Note: prune_at doesn't mean 'all data before were deleted' - it just mean stage.Prune function were run to this block. Because 1 stage may prune multiple data types to different prune distance.

                         stage_at        prune_at
Headers                  15298992        0
BlockHashes              15298992        0
Bodies                   15298992        0
Senders                  15298992        0
Execution                15298992        15298992
Translation              0               0
HashState                15298992        0
IntermediateHashes       15298992        15298992
AccountHistoryIndex      15298992        15298992
StorageHistoryIndex      15298992        15298992
LogIndex                 15298992        15298992
CallTraces               15298992        15298992
TxLookup                 15298992        15208992
Finish                   15298992        0
--
prune distance: --prune.h.older=90000 --prune.r.older=90000 --prune.t.older=90000 --prune.c.older=90000

sequence: EthTx=1700116363, NonCanonicalTx=15551

first header in db: 15009000
first body in db: 15009000

--
snapsthos: blocks=15207999, segments=15207999, indices=15207999
```

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

I started the node with:

```
./erigon-2022.08.01/build/bin/erigon \
    --datadir /mnt/node_data/erigon \
    --prune=hrtc \
    --http --http.addr 0.0.0.0 --http.api "eth,erigon,web3,net,debug,trace,txpool" --http.corsdomain "*"  \
    --private.api.addr 192.168.1.10:9091 \
    --metrics --metrics.addr 0.0.0.0 \
    --ws
```

#### Logs

looks normal
